description: From Middle English stageren, stakeren, from Old Norse stakra (“to push, stagger”). Cognate with dialectal Danish stagre.

entries.meaning: An unsteady movement of the body in walking or standing as if one were about to fall; a reeling motion.
examples: Put down the rosary beads folks, I believe hell may just have frozen over. Peyton Manning drops back, sees nothing open and runs for a first down. If you can call that running. More like the stagger of a wounded rhino. Did the job, though

entries.meaning: (veterinary medicine) A disease of horses and other animals, attended by reeling, unsteady gait or sudden falling.
The spacing out of various actions over time.
examples: I don’t include cured pork, although it is very nice, and rather than putting everything in the pan at once I prefer a stagger of ingredients, which ensures each one gets the right amount of time.

entries.meaning: (motor racing) The difference in circumference between the left and right tires on a racing vehicle. It is used on oval tracks to make the car turn better in the corners.
(aviation) The horizontal positioning of a biplane, triplane, or multiplane's wings in relation to one another.

verbs.description: stagger (third-person singular simple present staggers, present participle staggering, simple past and past participle staggered)

definitionGroups.group: To sway unsteadily, reel, or totter.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) In standing or walking, to sway from one side to the other as if about to fall; to stand or walk unsteadily; to reel or totter.
examples: She began to stagger across the room.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To cause to reel or totter.
examples: The powerful blow of his opponent's fist staggered the boxer.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To cease to stand firm; to begin to give way; to fail.
(intransitive) To begin to doubt and waver in purposes; to become less confident or determined; to hesitate.
examples: He [Abraham] staggered not at the promise of God through unbelief.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To cause to doubt and waver; to make to hesitate; to make less steady or confident; to shock.
examples: He will stagger the committee when he presents his report.

definitionGroups.group: (transitive) Have multiple groups doing the same thing in a uniform fashion, but starting at different, evenly spaced, times or places (attested from 1856).

entries.meaning: To arrange (a series of parts) on each side of a median line alternately, as the spokes of a wheel or the rivets of a boiler seam.
To arrange similar objects such that each is ahead or above and to one side of the next.
examples: We will stagger the starting positions for the race on the oval track.

entries.meaning: To schedule in intervals or at different times.
examples: We will stagger the run so the faster runners can go first, then the joggers.

entries.meaning: (UK) One who attends a stag night.
examples: Tallinn no longer takes pride in the title of 'favourite destination of British staggers'.
